summaries.body: A Papua New Guinea tribe whose funeral customs once included eating the decedent's brain developed resistance to a form of dementia, scientists said in a new study.
Six villages in Nepal were buried in a landslide caused by heavy rain, an official said. At least 15 people were thought to have been killed.
Ludvik Vaculik, a Czech intellectual whose eloquent 1968 critique of Communism, "Two Thousand Words," helped foster the short-lived "Prague Spring," died at 88.
Brazil's highest court struck down a contentious law under which subjects of unauthorized biographies could prevent them from being published or sold.
Twitter said it would double its staff in Singapore in the next two years as it seeks new users and advertisers in Asia.
Nike will replace Adidas as the N.B.A.’s official provider of on-court apparel starting in 2017. The eight-year deal is worth about $1 billion, an executive said.
Robert Chartoff, an Oscar-winning producer best known for "Raging Bull" and "Rocky," died at 81, his daughter said.

display_asset.caption: A hearing for the man accused of killing Etan Patz, whose first trial ended deadlocked, drew jurors who still advocate conviction.

summaries.body: Several members of the hung jury in the trial of Pedro Hernandez, accused of killing Etan Patz in 1979, showed up at his latest hearing, with one saying that he "needs to pay."

posts.footer: The Associated Press | The New York Times

summaries.body: South Korea's central bank cut its key interest rate to a new low of 1.5 percent, citing the potential of the country's MERS outbreak to hurt the economy.
A class-action lawsuit claims the Border Patrol near Tucson broke its own policies by regularly holding immigrants for more than 24 hours in freezing, overcrowded cells.
A former girlfriend of James E. Holmes, accused in a 2012 shooting at a Colorado theater, testified Wednesday that he sent her messages saying he wanted to kill people.
A committee that advises the F.D.A. recommended that the agency approve the second in a new class of drugs that can drive cholesterol levels down to unheard-of levels.
Gov. Rick Scott of Florida signed a law requiring women to wait at least 24 hours before having an abortion.
A new trial for the man who confessed to killing 6-year-old Etan Patz will open in 2016, a judge said on Wednesday.
Three Polish ministers and the country's parliamentary speaker have resigned after secret recordings of conversations were published by a magazine.
Floyd Mayweather Jr. has shattered the record for athlete earnings, taking in $300 million over the last 12 months. Tiger Woods held the previous record of $115 million in 2008.
Under a new policy, both men and women who work for a branch of the Virgin Group in Britain and Geneva will get up to a year of paid leave after having a child.

display_asset.caption: Bill Clinton spoke at a Clinton Global Initiative America meeting in Denver on Wednesday.

summaries.body: Former President Bill Clinton said on Wednesday that if his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, won the White House, he would no longer give paid speeches.
An oil spill described as an "environmental tragedy" is expected to reach the Pacific Coast in Colombia on Wednesday. Insurgents bombed a pipeline on Monday.
BMW unveiled its new flagship sedan, the 7-series, on Wednesday, focusing more on the car's digital prowess — like a removable tablet computer — than on horsepower.
Brain tumors can be more effectively treated by ascertaining their genetic characteristics, rather than studying tissue under a microscope, new research said.
Fitbit, the maker of wearable activity tracking devices, will face a second lawsuit from a rival, Jawbone. The complaint filed Wednesday accuses Fitbit of patent infringement.
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s first post on Instagram is a play on her memoir, “Hard Choices.” The “hard choice” in this case? What to wear.
The World Bank cut its global growth outlook for 2015 and urged the Federal Reserve to hold off on a rate increase.

display_asset.caption: Florence Welch of Florence and the Machine at Governors Ball on Friday.
display_asset.credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

summaries.body: Florence and the Machine, the British rock group led by Florence Welch, has its first No.1 album release with “How Big, How Blue, How Beautiful," Nielsen reported.
Nike will become the exclusive provider of on-court gear for the N.B.A., and the first to have its logo appear on N.B.A. uniforms. Adidas is the current provider.
The cost of cleaning up the oil spill on the California coast last month has reached $69 million so far, with costs running at $3 million a day, a company official said.
Senator Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential hopeful, denied an assertion that has cropped up on the Internet that he has dual citizenship with Israel.

posts.footer: Austin American-Statesman | The Chronicle of Higher Education

summaries.body: The University of Texas is investigating academic issues raised by The Chronicle of Higher Education, which reported that a former men's basketball player cheated on a test.
The United States posted a budget deficit of $82.4 billion last month, a 37 percent drop from the $130 billion deficit posted in May last year, the Treasury Department said.
Evidence of listeria was found at a Blue Bell plant in Alabama, the third in the company to test positive. The ice cream maker recalled all of its products earlier this year.
The United Nations said attacks on international peacekeepers and civilians in Sudan's Darfur region have been increasing, with negligible progress toward peace.
People lined the streets in Haltern, Germany, as a convoy of hearses took the remains of students and teachers killed in the Germanwings plane crash home for burial.
The Los Angeles City Council approved raising the minimum wage to $15 over the next five years. The ordinance awaits a signature from Mayor Eric Garcetti.
Abortion rights groups filed a motion to halt a court decision that allowed Texas to impose restrictions on abortions, and said they would take the case to the Supreme Court.
The U.S. ousted Russia as the world's biggest oil and natural-gas producer, according to data released by BP.

posts.footer: The Miami Herald | The New York Times

summaries.body: A Miami principal was reassigned after he wrote a Facebook post defending a police officer in McKinney, Tex., who resigned over his treatment of black teens at a pool party.
Raven-Symoné, who has appeared on ABC's "The View" 37 times as a guest co-host, will officially join the show, the network announced.
TeliaSonera, a Swedish company, said it took a 1.4 percent stake in Spotify for $115 million, just as Spotify prepares to compete with Apple in the music streaming market.
A federal judge approved $53.8 million in settlements for 82 unionized cleanup workers who said toxic dust near the World Trade Center site made them ill.
The Glendale City Council will consider ending the city's contract with the N.H.L.'s Arizona Coyotes at a meeting Wednesday, putting the team's future in doubt.
A prosecutor in Georgia said he had dismissed murder charges against a 23-year-old woman accused of inducing an abortion by taking pills.
Senator Johnny Isakson, Republican of Georgia, said he has been given a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease but he will continue to work and seek re-election.
The E.P.A. said greenhouse gases from aircrafts endanger human health, in what is seen as the first step toward regulating emissions from the aviation industry.

display_asset.credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times

summaries.body: Two buses collided in the Lincoln Tunnel between New York City and New Jersey, injuring at least 18 people and causing major traffic delays for morning commuters.
Microsoft will build the Surface Hub, a large touch-screen computer that costs up to $20,000, in Oregon. It joins a rare group of tech products that are made in America.
A top U.S. diplomat urged Pope Francis to take a tougher stance against President Vladimir V. Putin when they meet on Wednesday, the Russian leader's first visit since 2013.
Lionel Messi, the international soccer star, is set to face trial for tax fraud. The authorities say he defrauded Spain of 4.1 million euros, or $4.6 million, in income tax.
President Pierre Nkurunziza of Burundi said the country's presidential election would be on July 15. It was delayed after six weeks of violence related to his bid for a third term.
R. Timothy Hunt, who won the Nobel Prize in 2001, apologized for saying in a speech that women in labs "cry" when criticized and "fall in love" with colleagues.
China’s economic slowdown is the greatest challenge facing European companies there, with some reporting falling revenue and plans for layoffs, a new report said.
A woman was taken to a Hong Kong hospital on suspicion she had contracted the potentially deadly MERS virus, as an outbreak in South Korea raised concerns in the region.

display_asset.caption: Mount Kinabalu, Malaysia’s highest peak, on Saturday, a day after an earthquake left 18 people dead.

summaries.body: Four Western trekkers who were accused of taking nude photos on Malaysia’s highest peak were ordered detained pending an investigation into public obscenity charges.
The Vatican has agreed to share tax information with the United States in its latest move to improve the reputation of its scandal-marred bank and crack down on tax cheats.
Embroiled in a corruption investigation, FIFA has delayed the bidding process to host the 2026 World Cup.
Pakistan executed a man who was 15 when he was sentenced to death for murder and whose lawyers say was tortured into confessing.
Michelle Kwan, a former figure skater and Olympic medal winner, is joining Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign, working from Brooklyn on outreach efforts, aides said.
A South Korea-World Health Organization mission studying an outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome in the country recommended that schools be reopened.
Dozens of suspects have been arrested in an investigation into a cybercrime gang that siphoned millions of euros from victims' accounts, European officials said.
Sikhs in Afghanistan have been persecuted for decades, and community leaders say their numbers have fallen to a few thousand as more choose to leave the country.
David Miliband, the brother of the former Labour leader, said in an interview with CNN that the party had "turned the page backwards" since entering the opposition.
Bangkok University, which like many Thai universities requires students to wear uniforms, modified its dress code to accommodate transgender students.

posts.footer: Jerry Kelly, a typographer, on Hermann Zapf, who died last week at 96 and who invented well-known typefaces like Optima, which is used on the Sept. 11 memorial in New York (pictured), via The New York Times

display_asset.caption: The Sept. 11 memorial in New York uses the typeface Optima, designed by Mr. Zapf.

summaries.body: What Michelangelo was to sculpture and Beethoven was to music, that’s what Hermann Zapf is to type design and calligraphy.
An engine misfire at the International Space Station caused its position in orbit to change, but the crew was in no danger, Russia's space agency said.
Officials in Los Angeles voted to develop a plan to distribute Truvada, a controversial H.I.V. drug, to residents who are at a high risk of contracting the virus.
The mayor of West Hollywood, Calif., officiated at a wedding for seven gay and lesbian couples from China, who won a contest sponsored by two Chinese tech companies.
Wisconsin lawmakers voted to repeal a 48-hour waiting period to purchase a handgun, a measure Gov. Scott Walker has said he would sign into law.
A Texas federal judge handed down a $663 million judgment against a guardrail maker accused of producing a faulty product that can jam and spear through vehicles.
The remains of 44 victims of the Germanwings plane crash arrived in Germany, where they will be returned to families for burial.
Iran and the U.S. may be headed toward a possible confrontation over the purchase of nine jetliners by an Iranian airline blacklisted under American sanctions.
A retrial began Tuesday for Sgt. Lawrence Hutchins III, above, a Marine whose 2007 conviction for the murder of an Iraqi man during the war was thrown out in 2013.
Missouri executed Richard Strong, the fourth man to die by injection in the state this year. He was convicted of killing his girlfriend and her 2-year-old daughter in 2000.
About 2,000 posters from the World War I era, including the famous Uncle Sam poster, will be sold later this month, Guernsey's auction house said on Tuesday.
Seventy-nine percent of Americans believe it is more common for people to fall out of the middle class than rise up to it, according to new research.
The Montreal Olympic Stadium was nearly empty as Spain and Costa Rica made their debut in the Women's World Cup. The Group E opener ended in a 1-1 draw.

posts.footer: The first photo of Secretary of State John Kerry since he broke his leg in a bicycle accident in France on May 31, via Twitter

summaries.body: Feeling good a week after surgery. Good chats today w/@AmbassadorRice & @StateDept senior team. The work continues! http://t.co/TzRpR0khQs

display_asset.caption: A chimpanzee drinking palm wine. Some of the animals were observed stealing the beverage from human villagers in Guinea.
display_asset.credit: Gaku Ohashi, Chubu University and Wildlife Research Center, Kyoto University

summaries.body: Scientists have found a group of chimpanzees that make a habit of stealing alcoholic drinks made from tree sap from villagers in Guinea, a report published Tuesday said.
As Arkansas' top court weighs an appeal to the state's same-sex marriage ban, a judge ordered officials to recognize more than 500 marriages performed in 2014.

posts.footer: Mark Lazarus, the NBC Sports chairman, wants N.H.L. players to end the playoff beard tradition, via The Chicago Tribune

summaries.body: The players won't like this, but I wish they all would stop growing beards in the postseason.
Advance ticket sales for "Jurassic World," expected to debut to $115 million this weekend, are outpacing all major summer blockbusters from last year.
The release of Albert Woodfox, the last incarcerated member of the group called the Angola 3 who spent decades in solitary confinement, has been temporarily blocked.
Mariano Rivera Jr., right, the son of legendary former Yankees closer Mariano Rivera, was chosen by the Nationals in the fourth round of the M.L.B. draft.
The Indian Army inflicted "significant casualties" on insurgent groups along its border with Myanmar, an official said, days after rebels killed 18 Indian soldiers.

display_asset.caption: “Pointing Man,” a 5-foot-high bronze figure by Alberto Giacometti depicting a gaunt figure with extended arms, has been in the same private collection for 45 years.

summaries.body: Steven A. Cohen, the hedge fund billionaire, was the bidder who paid $141.3 million for Alberto Giacometti's "Pointing Man," setting an auction high for a sculpture.
American Airlines said it would begin operating a direct flight from Los Angeles to Sydney, Australia, this year, a first in more than two decades.
A judge dismissed three jurors in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 in a Colorado theater in 2012, for discussing news accounts of the case.
A recommendation to shrink the size of carry-on bags allowed in airplanes was proposed at a meeting of global airline C.E.O.s, but no U.S. airlines have signed on yet.
Anna, Olaf, Kristoff and other characters will make appearances at Disney's Epcot Center next year in a new ride that takes visitors past scenes from the movie "Frozen."
Six “Raging Grannies” activists were arrested for blocking train traffic by chaining themselves together on rocking chairs to protest Shell’s Arctic drilling plans.
A federal appeals court upheld abortion restrictions in Texas that require clinics to meet hospital-like standards. Only a handful of clinics do, all in major metropolitan areas.
Virginia's Supreme Court temporarily blocked the planned closure of 114-year-old Sweet Briar College, saying debate over the fate of the school for women is "far from over."
The University of Louisville extended Rick Pitino's contract through the 2025-26 men's basketball season. The coach's salary will increase to $5.093 million in 2016.
A 102-year-old German woman was awarded a doctorate on Tuesday, almost 80 years after the Nazis prevented her from taking her final exam at Hamburg University.
Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said gay and lesbian troops would, for the first time, be protected from discrimination by the Pentagon's equal opportunity policy.
After losing touch last week, LightSail, a private spacecraft meant to demonstrate solar propulsion, sent back to Earth a selfie showing its sail stretched out.
The Federal Railroad Administration issued a safety advisory for passenger railroads in the wake of two major accidents, focusing mainly on controlling excessive train speed.
Following up on a pledge to spend $300 million over five years to improve diversity, Intel Corp. said it would back companies with women and minorities in leadership roles.
The head of the Cleveland police union criticized community leaders' plans to seek warrants for the officers involved in the fatal shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice.
After almost 50 years, "Saul and David," one of Rembrandt’s most important biblical works, was declared authentic. Above, conservators at work.
The mother of a young Frenchman who converted to Islam and went to join fighters in Syria is suing France for failing to stop him leaving the airport in Nice.
